Title: Temporal Structures of Gender Inequalities in Asian and Western Welfare Regimes

This project examines how different welfare regimes shape gender inequalities in time use, unpaid work, and daily activities, and their consequences for family outcomes. Grounded in Esping-Andersen's "three worlds" framework, our study compares East Asian societies (China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan) with Western societies, exploring the intersections of gender roles, welfare regimes, and time use. We will investigate how public policies, social norms, and modern technology influence the gender division of labor, care provision, domestic labor, leisure time, and enjoyment. 

Using a cross-national and historical comparative approach, we will analyze time diary data and household panel data to identify patterns and trends at the household, societal, and life course levels. Our study will provide a nuanced understanding of how welfare regimes shape gender inequalities in time use and daily activities, ultimately affecting family outcomes. By shedding light on the temporal structures of gender inequalities, this project aims to inform policymakers and scholars on how to design more equitable and effective social policies that promote gender equality and well-being.

This research project aims to investigate the temporal structures of gender inequalities in Asian and Western welfare regimes, with a focus on the interplay between gender roles, welfare regimes, and time use. Building on Esping-Andersen's "three worlds" framework, this study will comparatively analyze the experiences of China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan, and contrast them with Western societies. By examining how men and women allocate their time between unpaid work, daily activities, and leisure, this project will uncover the underlying mechanisms driving gender inequalities in different welfare regimes.

Using a cross-national and historical comparative approach, this study will draw on time diary data and household panel data to analyze the impact of public policies, modern technology, and care provision on the gender division of labor, social inequality, and enjoyment. The study will be conducted at the household, societal, and life course levels, providing a comprehensive understanding of how gender inequalities are shaped by welfare regimes and time use patterns.

By examining the temporal structures of gender inequalities, this project will provide new insights into the ways in which welfare regimes influence family outcomes and contribute to a more nuanced understanding of the complex relationships between gender, time, and inequality. The results of this study will inform policy debates on promoting gender equality and improving family well-being in diverse cultural and institutional contexts.

Building on Esping-Andersen's "three worlds" framework, this study will conduct a cross-national and historical comparative analysis of China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan, comparing them to Western societies.

The project's comparative approach will enable the identification of both convergent and divergent trends in gender inequalities between East Asian and Western societies, shedding light on the role of modern technology in shaping life schedules and gender roles. Ultimately, this project seeks to contribute to a deeper understanding of the complex relationships between welfare regimes, gender roles, and time use, and to inform policy debates on how to address the persisting gender inequalities in both Asian and Western societies.
